column4: Under Armour forecasts higher Q1 revenue on full-price push, posts surprise profit
column5: (Reuters) - Under Armour forecast first-quarter revenue above estimates on higher sales at full price, as a strong Asia-Pacific and online performance helped it post a surprise holiday-quarter profit on Wednesday, sending its shares up 10%.
column6: The company’s results were also buoyed by an 11% jump in sales at its high-margin, direct-to-consumer units in the fourth quarter, helped by a 25% growth in e-commerce sales.
column7: Several athletic apparel makers, including Under Armour and Nike, have been looking to direct a home workout-led demand boom for their training shoes and running shorts to their own stores and away from low-margin wholesale channels.
column8: Under Armour forecast its current-quarter revenue to jump about 20%, higher than a Refinitiv IBES estimate of 17.65%, on lower discounting and more full-price sales.
column9: “In our retail stores, we are working to evolve concepts to drive more profitable formats, particularly for our full-price brand house locations,” Chief Executive Officer Patrik Frisk told analysts.
column10: It also forecast adjusted profit per share to be about 3 cents, while analysts expect a loss of 5 cents.
column11: Retail analysts have also said Under Armour’s move to expand its product line related to brands backed by actor Dwayne “The Rock” Johnson and NBA star Stephen Curry would boost its sales.
column12: “UAA’s turnaround continues to pose an intriguing setup as the brand re-bases in North America to support long-term growth,” RBC Capital Markets analyst Kate Fitzsimons said.
column13: The company’s overall revenue fell about 3% to $1.40 billion in the three months ended Dec. 31, but topped estimates of $1.27 billion, as its Asia-Pacific unit posted a 26% growth.
column14: Excluding items, it posted a surprise per-share profit of 12 cents, compared with market estimates of a loss of 7 cents.
column15: Under Armour also forecast 2021 profit in line with estimates, while it expects revenue growth percentage to be in high single-digits in 2021. Analysts estimate revenue to rise by 12.65%.

column4: Consumers hot under collar in new lawsuit over Under Armour clothing line
column5: Sportswear maker Under Armour Inc has been hit with a proposed class action accusing it of misleading consumers about the purported performance-enhancing features of its “Rush” line of products.
column6: The lawsuit, filed Monday in Brooklyn federal court by Spencer Sheehan of Sheehan & Associates on behalf of New York resident Jonathan Dill, claims the Baltimore-based company falsely claimed that the products’ “mineral-infused fabrics” reflect heat emitted, similar to a sauna, promoting faster recovery.
column7: To read the full story on Westlaw Today, click here: bit.ly/34aqs20

column4: Ravens place three players on COVID-19 list
column5: (Reuters) - The Baltimore Ravens on Monday said the team had placed running backs Mark Ingram and J.K. Dobbins, as well as defensive tackle Brandon Williams on the Reserve/COVID-19 list ahead of the team’s Thanksgiving day showdown with the Pittsburgh Steelers.
column6: Earlier in the day, the team had said multiple members of the organization were self-isolating and that contact tracing efforts were underway after the team received positive test results late Sunday night.
column7: The team closed its practice facility on Monday morning but reopened it later in the day.
column8: “We got started with virtual meetings this afternoon,” coach John Harbaugh said during a video call with reporters.
column9: “We’re just carrying forward with our normal schedule at this point, working hard and getting ready for a big challenge Thursday night against the undefeated Steelers.”
column10: Also on Monday, the Minnesota Vikings announced that star wide receiver Adam Thielen had been placed on the Reserve/COVID-19 list.
column11: The Reserve/COVID-19 list is for players who either test positive for the virus or have had close contact with a person who has. The players return is subject to “medical clearance.”

column4: NFL-Ravens report multiple COVID-19 cases, close practice facility
column5: Nov 23 (Reuters) - The Baltimore Ravens on Monday said multiple members of their organization had tested positive for COVID-19 and were self-isolating and as a result the team was closing its practice facility.
column6: “We have started the process of contact tracing, and during this time, the Under Armour Performance Center will be closed, with all team activities conducted virtually,” the team said in a statement on Twitter.
column7: “We will continue to work closely with and follow guidance from the NFL, team doctors and medical trainers.”
column8: The Ravens (6-4) are scheduled to take on the undefeated Pittsburgh Steelers (10-0) on Thursday in a mouth-watering Thanksgiving day match-up. (Reporting by Rory Carroll in Los Angeles; Editing by Ken Ferris)

column4: Under Armour expects demand for sneakers, face masks to drive annual revenue
column5: (Reuters) - Under Armour Inc UA.NUAA.N forecast its annual revenue above Wall Street expectations on Friday, as a pandemic-driven trend to exercise outdoors resulted in a surge in demand for running shoes and face masks.
column6: The Baltimore-based company’s shares rose as much as 11.6%, after it also decided to sell its MyFitnessPal health tracking platform for $345 million to private equity firm Francisco Partners.
column7: As gym attendance drops due to the chance of the coronavirus spreading more in confined spaces, more people have opted to go running or biking outdoors, driving up sales of Under Armour’s HOVR line of training shoes and other fitness gear.
column8: The company’s footwear revenue rose 19% to nearly $300 million in the third quarter. Accessories revenue rose 23% to $145 million, which Under Armour said was driven by sale of athlete-focused “sports masks”.
column9: Like bigger rival Nike Inc NKE.N, a large chunk of Under Armour's new demand was coming from its website and app, which pushed its e-commerce business up more than 50%.
column10: Overall quarterly revenue was largely flat at $1.43 billion in the quarter, pressured by a drop in demand at North American department stores and a 6% fall in apparel revenue, but was above expectations of $1.16 billion.
column11: Excluding certain items, Under Armour earned 26 cents per share, beating expectations of 3 cents per share, according to Refinitiv data.
column12: The company said the sale of MyFitnessPal, which it bought in 2015 for $475 million, gives it more investment firepower and simplifies its larger digital fitness business.
column13: It forecast full-year revenue to fall by a high-teen percentage, compared with estimates of a 25.7% drop.
column14: The company said it expects an annual adjusted loss of 47 cents to 49 cents per share, smaller than the 72 cents per share loss estimated by analysts.

column4: Under Armour to lay off 600 employees globally
column5: (Reuters) - Sportswear maker Under Armour Inc UAA.NUA.N said on Tuesday it will lay off about 600 employees from its global workforce, citing the impact brought on by the coronavirus pandemic to its business.
column6: The company expects to incur about $235 million in charges, including up to $135 million for contract termination and other restructuring costs, it said in a filing bit.ly/35jNwfY.
column7: The company also raised its restructuring cost for the year by $75 million and now expects it to be about $550 million to $600 million.
column8: Under Armour said it expects majority of remaining restructuring charges to occur by end of the year.
column9: In April, the company had said it would temporarily lay off about 600 workers at its U.S.-based distribution centers.

column4: Under Armour warns of margin pressure for rest of 2020
column5: (Reuters) - Under Armour Inc UAA.NUA.N said it expects margins to be pressured for the rest of the year on the back of increased promotions, even as online demand helped the sportswear maker post a smaller-than-expected loss.
column6: Shares of the Baltimore-based company, which surged during before the opening bell, were down about 7% in morning trading.
column7: Chief Financial Officer David Bergman warned on a call with analysts the company might not have adequate supply to meet higher demand, if the second half of the year recovers at a faster-than-expected rate.
column8: “Given the dramatic impacts across the retail landscape due to store closures, and inability to reduce supply as fast as demand, we’re anticipating that a highly promotional environment will materialize in the second half.”
column9: A major portion of sales to off-price channels being planned in the third and fourth quarters could result in “meaningful” gross margin pressures for the rest of the year, Bergman added.
column10: Under Armour has been trying to reduce its dependence on the low-margin wholesale business, through which it sells to department and off-price stores.
column11: However, with increased promotional activity expected in the second half of the year, the company is anticipating more sales to off-price stores.
column12: Under Armour beat analysts’ estimates for second-quarter revenue, as consumers shopped more online with several stores being shut due to the virus lockdowns.
column13: During the quarter, its wholesales business revenue dropped 58%, while that of direct-to-consumer sales fell only 13%, helping gross margins rise 280 basis points.
column14: Net revenue fell about 41% to $707.6 million in the quarter ended June 30, but beat estimates of $558.5 million, according to IBES data from Refinitiv.
column15: On an adjusted basis, the company lost 31 cents per share, compared to analysts’ estimates of 41 cents.

column4: Under Armour revenue beats on e-commerce strength
column5: July 31 (Reuters) - Sportswear maker Under Armour Inc beat analysts’ estimates for quarterly revenue on Friday, as consumers shopped more online during the coronavirus lockdowns, sending its shares up about 8% in premarket trading.
column6: Net revenue fell about 41% to $707.6 million in the second quarter ended June 30, compared with estimates of $558.5 million, according to IBES data from Refinitiv.
column7: Under Armour reported a bigger net loss of $182.9 million, or 40 cents per share, in the quarter, compared with a loss of $17.3 million, or 4 cents per share, a year earlier. (Reporting by Nivedita Balu in Bengaluru; Editing by Shounak Dasgupta)

column4: Under Armour executives receive Wells notice from SEC
column5: (Reuters) - Under Armour Inc disclosed on Monday that its top executives had received a Wells notice from the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission related to an investigation about the sportswear maker’s accounting practices.
column6: Last year, the company said it was cooperating with federal investigators in connection with a probe about whether it shifted sales from quarter to quarter to meet objectives.
column7: While a Wells notice does not necessarily mean the recipients have violated any law, the SEC issues the letter to firms when it is planning to bring an enforcement action against them.
column8: A filing on Monday showed that the staff of the SEC is recommending that the regulatory body file an enforcement action against the company, founder and executive chairman Kevin Plank and Chief Financial Officer David Bergman, that would allege certain violations of federal securities laws. (bit.ly/2BCWOHA)
column9: Under Armour and the executives said that their actions were appropriate and they intend to pursue the Wells Notice process.
column10: Shares of the company were down nearly 4% in premarket trading.
column11: (This story corrects paragraph 4 to say Kevin Plank is the founder and executive chairman, not CEO)

column4: BRIEF-Under Armour Seeks Buyer For Myfitnesspal App - The Information
column5: July 7 (Reuters) -
column6: * UNDER ARMOUR SEEKS BUYER FOR MYFITNESSPAL APP - THE INFORMATION Source text : [ID:bit.ly/3fdZnOY] Further company coverage:

column4: Under Armour to discontinue record apparel partnership with UCLA
column5: (Reuters) - Athletic apparel maker Under Armour UAA.N said on Saturday it will discontinue its partnership with UCLA - a 15-year, $280 million accord announced in 2016 that was billed as the largest apparel deal in the history of American collegiate sports.
column6: The University of California, Los Angeles promised to fight the move.
column7: The Baltimore-based company said in an emailed statement that it made the decision to terminate the agreement with UCLA - a member of the Pac-12 athletics conference - because “we have been paying for marketing benefits that we have not received for an extended time period.”
column8: The agreement with UCLA allowed the company to terminate the deal in such an event and it is exercising its right, Under Armour added.
column9: “We are exploring all our options to resist Under Armour’s actions,” UCLA said in a statement. “We remain committed to providing our hard-working staff and student-athletes with the footwear, apparel and equipment needed to train and compete at the highest level.”
column10: Under Armour has competed with other leading apparel makers for agreements with major intercollegiate sports programs.
column11: In May 2016 the company had hailed the agreement, which took effect in 2017, as “the largest apparel deal in the history of the NCAA (National Collegiate Athletic Association), reaffirming UCLA’s status as a world-class institution and Under Armour’s position as a global leader committed to collegiate athletics.”
column12: Under Armour also has apparel deals with schools including Notre Dame, Wisconsin, Auburn, Texas Tech and Utah, according to its website.
column13: Company officials could not immediately be reached to comment on whether it would seek to end similar deals with other universities.
column14: Major peers that also have apparel deals with schools include Nike NKE.N and Adidas ADSGn.DE. Representatives of those two companies were not immediately available for comment outside normal business hours.
column15: As part of the partnership, Under Armour was to have exclusively designed and supplied the footwear, apparel and equipment for training and game-day uniforms for all UCLA’s men’s and women’s varsity athletic teams, the company had said.

column4: Under Armour informs UCLA it wants to terminate deal with school- LA Times
column5: June 27 (Reuters) - Under Armour has informed University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA) that it wants to terminate a $280 million deal that it signed with the school in 2016, the Los Angeles Times reported here on Saturday.
column6: “We are exploring all of our options to resist Under Armour’s actions and will share more information as we can. We want to reassure you that UCLA Athletics remains committed to providing our hard-working staff and student-athletes with the footwear, apparel and equipment needed to train and compete at the highest level,” the report said, citing a letter by Dan Guerrero, the school’s outgoing athletic director.
column7: Both Under Armour and UCLA did not immediately respond to a Reuters request for comment.
column8: The athletic apparel maker announced a 15- year partnership with UCLA in 2016. (Reporting by Juby Babu in Bengaluru; editing by Diane Craft)

column4: Under Armour warns 2nd quarter revenue could more than halve, shares tank
column5: (Reuters) - Under Armour Inc UA.NUAA.N forecast on Monday a 50% to 60% drop in second-quarter revenue as most of its stores remained closed because of the COVID-19 pandemic, sending the athletic apparel maker's shares down about 11%.
column6: The Baltimore-based company also reported bigger-than-expected loss for the first quarter and revenue that missed Wall Street estimates.
column7: About 80% of Under Armour’s business around the world remained closed since April, Chief Financial Officer David Bergman said, even as most of its own stores and wholesale operations in Asia have already reopened.
column8: “Although we do anticipate that our business will gradually reopen in the coming weeks and months, we believe there will be a number of challenges ahead for us,” Bergman told analysts.
column9: Bergman cited uncertainty how much consumers will spend once stores reopen and a threat of deep discounts retailers may offer to woo shoppers back.
column10: Last month, the company temporarily laid off about 600 staff at its U.S.-based distribution centers, extended store closures, and withdrew its forecast for the year.
column11: Several retail and department stores, including Neiman Marcus and J.C. Penney that are on the brink of bankruptcy, that sell Under Armour merchandise were also closed during the last few weeks of the quarter.
column12: The brand was already struggling with competition from the likes of Nike Inc NKE.N and Lululemon Athletica LULU.O which have been able to attract more shoppers with their new launches, limited edition products and ad campaigns.
column13: “Under Armour’s brand position in North America was stressed going into the crisis, but performance in the region in Q1 was even worse than we expected, given that stores were open until mid-March,” Bernstein analyst Jamie Merriman said.
column14: In North America, its biggest segment which accounted for about 65% of total sales in the quarter, revenue slumped 28% to $609 million.
column15: Overall, net revenue fell about 23% to $930.2 million in the first quarter ended March 31.
column16: Under Armour reported a net loss of $589.7 million, or $1.30 per share, compared with a profit of 5 cents per share, a year earlier.
column17: Analysts had forecast revenue of $949 million, according to IBES data from Refinitiv. Exluding one-time items, Under Armour reported a loss of 34 cents per share, compared with analysts’ expectations of a 19 cent loss.
column18: The company expects to reduce its originally planned operating expenses for the year by about $325 million.

column4: Under Armour's quarterly revenue tumbles 23% amid health crisis
column5: May 11 (Reuters) - Athletic apparel maker Under Armour Inc on Monday reported a 22.8% fall in quarterly revenue, as several retailers across the world remained shut due to the COVID-19 pandemic.
column6: The company reported a net loss of $589.7 million, or $1.3 per share, in the first quarter ended March 31, compared with a profit of $22.5 million, or 5 cents per share, a year earlier.
column7: Net revenue fell to $930.2 million from $1.20 billion. (Reporting by Nivedita Balu in Bengaluru Editing by Tomasz Janowski)

column4: BRIEF-Under Armour Says To Close All Stores In North America From March 16 Through March 28
column5: March 15 (Reuters) - Under Armour Inc:
column6: * UNDER ARMOUR WILL CLOSE ALL STORES IN NORTH AMERICA FROM MARCH 16 THROUGH MARCH 28, 2020
column7: * UNDER ARMOUR WILL CLOSE ALL STORES IN NORTH AMERICA FROM MARCH 16 THROUGH MARCH 28, 2020
column8: * ALL TEAMMATES TO RECEIVE PAY DURING STORE CLOSURES IN NORTH AMERICA Source text for Eikon: Further company coverage:

column4: Under Armour shares drop after surprise profit decline warning for 2020
column5: (Reuters) - Under Armour Inc UA.NUAA.N on Tuesday forecast a surprise drop in 2020 profit, blaming ongoing weakness in its North American business and the coronavirus outbreak in China, sending its shares tumbling as much as 16%.
column6: The company has been losing market share to rival sportswear makers such as Nike Inc NKE.N and Adidas ADSGn.DE in a saturated North America market, which accounts for about 70% of Under Armour's revenue.
column7: To keep and bring in more customers, it has been forced to offer big discounts at retail chains and department stores in its home market, squeezing profits.
column8: “I’m not satisfied with where we are today,” Patrik Frisk said on his first conference call after taking over as chief executive officer. Frisk - only the second CEO in the company’s two-decade history - took over from founder Kevin Plank in January.
column9: “A combination of demand challenges and distribution dynamics is materially impacting our business,” Frisk said, adding that the problems were most evident in the company’s full-price wholesale and e-commerce businesses.
column10: Shares of the company were down 16% at $17.24 in early trading.
column11: Under Armour now expects revenue in North America to decline at a mid- to high-single-digit percentage rate in 2020, while it expects international sales to grow in the low double-digit percentage rate.
column12: “The magnitude of the decline is surprising,” Telsey Advisory Group analyst Cristina Fernandez said.
column13: The slowdown in North America has forced the Stephen Curry-shoe maker to revisit plans of opening a flagship store in New York City, a hot spot for footwear brands, as part of a new cost-cutting measure.
column14: Under Armour estimated $325 million to $425 million in pre-tax charges for the year due to the plan.
column15: The company said the coronavirus outbreak in China, which has killed more than a thousand people and forced several retailers to close and revise their forecasts, would have a $50 million to $60 million hit on first-quarter sales.
column16: Full-year revenue is expected to be down in the low single-digit percent range, Under Armour said, in contrast to analysts’ expectations for a 4.2% rise.
column17: The company also said profit per share would be between 10 cents and 13 cents, compared with 20 cents a year earlier and Wall Street estimates of 47 cents.
column18: For the fourth quarter, net revenue rose 3.7% to $1.44 billion, but missed estimates of $1.47 billion, according to IBES data from Refinitiv. Adjusted earnings of 10 cents per share also fell below expectations by a penny.

column4: Under Armour cuts revenue forecast; federal probe weighs on shares
column5: (Reuters) - Under Armour Inc UA.NUAA.N on Monday cut its forecast for annual revenue for a second time this year, the latest sign of problems for the sportswear maker that is facing a federal probe into its accounting practices.
column6: Shares of the company closed about 19% lower after a media report that the company was being investigated for shifting sales from quarter to quarter to appear financially healthier.
column7: In a conference call with analysts, Under Armour executives defended the company’s accounting practices and disclosures, and said they were cooperating with the federal investigators.
column8: The company is facing increasing competition from big players like Nike Inc NKE.N in the United States, its largest market, and to gain market share it has been trying to sell merchandise directly to customers through its own retail stores and online at full prices.
column9: However, the shift is yet to yield results for the company as most of its customers are used to buying merchandise in department and retail stores at a discounted price.
column10: While the company’s plan to cut its sales through off-price channels has boosted margins, Under Armour said it will impact its growth in annual revenue.
column11: “(We) don’t have much excess product to sell in the off-price channel,” Chief Operating Officer Patrik Frisk told analysts. He will replace long-time Chief Executive Officer Kevin Plank early next year.
column12: The sportswear maker now expects revenue growth of about 2% in fiscal 2019 compared with the prior forecast of a 3% to 4% rise.
column13: Fewer sales at discounted prices boosted margins by 220 basis points in the third quarter, helping its quarterly profit beat market expectations.
column14: The company also forecast annual profit to be at he higher end of its prior range of about 33 cents to 34 cents per share.
column15: “You expect that sometimes a company’s growth will start leveling out... but if they are trying to postpone the inevitable by messing with their accounting practices... That’s bad,” Paula Rosenblum, a retail analyst with RSR Research, said.
column16: Net income rose 40% to $102.3 million or 23 cents per share in the quarter, beating analysts’ estimates of 18 cents, according to IBES data from Refinitiv.
column17: Net revenue fell about 1% to $1.43 billion, but was above analyst expectation of $1.41 billion.

column4: Under Armour faces U.S. federal probe over accounting practices: WSJ
column5: (Reuters) - Under Armour Inc UAA.N is under investigation by U.S. federal law enforcement officials over whether the sportswear maker shifted sales from quarter to quarter to appear financially healthier, the Wall Street Journal reported on Sunday.
column6: The Baltimore-based company confirmed that it is under investigation and is cooperating with the Justice Department and U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission. It also defended its accounting practices and disclosures.
column7: The Journal, citing unnamed sources, said in its report here that a criminal inquiry is being conducted by Justice Department prosecutors, who are also coordinating with civil investigators at the SEC.
column8: In an emailed statement, an Under Armour spokesperson said, “The company began responding in July 2017 to requests for documents and information relating primarily to its accounting practices and related disclosures, and the company firmly believes that its accounting practices and disclosures were appropriate.”
column9: Last month, Under Armour said longtime Chief Executive Officer Kevin Plank was stepping down from the role next year, handing the reins of the company to operations head Patrik Frisk in an attempt to help battle brutal competition from Nike Inc NKE.N and Adidas AG ADSGn.DE in the United States.
column10: The company, which is due to report third-quarter results on Monday, has been restructuring its operations as it struggles to stand out in the United States, its biggest market, where it has been introducing products to shore up market share.
column11: In July, Under Armour cut its full-year revenue forecast and said it expected a slight decline in North America revenue for fiscal 2019 as demand at its stores and online faced pressure from relentless competition from bigger rivals.

column4: Under Armour faces federal probe over accounting practices - WSJ
column5: Nov 3 (Reuters) - Under Armour Inc is being probed by U.S. federal law enforcement officials, examining whether the sportswear maker shifted sales from quarter to quarter to appear healthier, the Wall Street Journal reported on Sunday.
column6: A criminal Inquiry is being conducted by U.S. Justice Department prosecutors, who are also coordinating with civil investigators at the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission, the report here added, citing a source.
column7: Under Armour did not immediately respond to a request seeking comment outside regular business hours.
column8: Last month, Under Armour said longtime Chief Executive Officer Kevin Plank was stepping down from the role next year, handing the reins of the sportswear maker to operations head Patrik Frisk, in an attempt to help battle brutal competition from Nike Inc and Adidas AG in the United States.

column4: Under Armour CEO to step aside after two decades; insider to replace
column5: (Reuters) - Under Armour Inc UAA.N founder Kevin Plank will hand the reins of the sportswear maker to operations head Patrik Frisk, hoping a change in leadership will help battle brutal competition from Nike and Adidas in the United States.
column6: Plank has been the company’s chief executive for more than two decades, turning it into a popular name in sportswear, but struggling to generate consistent sales growth.
column7: He brought in Frisk in 2017 from footwear and accessories company Aldo Group to help steer a turnaround plan that included store closures, job cuts and fewer promotions to bolster profit margins.
column8: “We view his capabilities as an operator favorably, and believe the regime will have continuity from Plank’s leadership,” Stifel analyst Jim Duffy said.
column9: Duffy added the change in leadership would not lead to any immediate strategy changes for Under Armour.
column10: Frisk will continue to report to Plank, who will stay on as executive chairman and brand chief, Under Armour said.
column11: Plank also has a majority voting control of the company as he beneficially owns all outstanding Class B common stock, which has 10 votes per share.
column12: Frisk will take over at the start of next year and will be tasked with propping up the company’s sales in the United States, where it has been introducing products such as new Curry sneaker and HOVR shoes at a faster pace to shore up market share.
column13: In an interview with CNBC on Tuesday, Frisk said the rebound in its North America business would take time.
column14: Shares of the company, which have risen nearly 14% this year, rose 3% on Tuesday following the announcement.

column4: Under Armour CEO steps down, taps insider Patrik Frisk for top role
column5: Oct 22 (Reuters) - Under Armour Inc said on Tuesday long-time Chief Executive Officer Kevin Plank plans to step down from the role next year and be succeeded by Chief Operating Officer Patrik Frisk.
column6: Frisk, 56, will take over from Plank, who will become executive chairman. (Reporting by Aishwarya Venugopal in Bengaluru; Editing by Bernard Orr)

column4: Under Armour sales growth in North America trails Nike again; shares sink
column5: (Reuters) - Sportswear maker Under Armour Inc UA.NUAA.N on Tuesday cut its full-year revenue forecast for North America as demand at its stores and online faced pressure from relentless competition from bigger rivals Nike and Adidas.
column6: Shares of the company fell as much as 20% as it struggles to stand out in the United States, its biggest market, where it has been introducing products such as new Curry sneaker and HOVR shoes at a faster pace to shore up market share.
column7: Under Armour has also been opening more company-owned stores and beefing up its online business, but the strategy failed to deliver in the quarter, with North America sales falling 3%. In contrast, Nike reported a 7% rise in sales from the region in the last reported quarter.
column8: “With the sports apparel space becoming increasingly crowded, Under Armour needs to carve out a more distinct and edgy position,” said Neil Saunders, managing director at research firm GlobalData.
column9: Chief Operating Officer Patrik Frisk said in a post earnings call that while more customers visited its app and website, that did not translate into sales.
column10: “In direct-to-consumer, we’re experiencing softer than anticipated demand,” Frisk said, adding that sales volume at its stores were also weak.
column11: “There’s a lot of work that we’re putting into getting better from an e-commerce digital perspective.”
column12: Nike and Adidas have pumped money into its online businesses, which have been driving their strong results.
column13: While online sales for Adidas grew 40% in the latest reported quarter, Under Armour’s direct-to-consumer unit grew just 2% in the quarter.
column14: The Baltimore-based firm said it now expected a slight decline in North America revenue for fiscal 2019 compared with a prior forecast of flat revenue.
column15: However, it stuck to its overall growth target on higher demand for shoes and apparel abroad as higher spending in international markets powered growth in Europe and Asia Pacific.
column16: The company’s net loss narrowed to $17.3 million in the quarter ended June 30. Excluding certain items, Under Armour posted a loss of 3 cents per share, while analysts were expecting a loss of 5 cents.
column17: Net revenue rose about 1% to $1.19 billion roughly in line with analysts’ expectation.
column18: Class A shares of the company have risen 55% so far this year and were trading at $23.69, down 13%.

column4: Under Armour quarterly revenue rises 1%
column5: July 30 (Reuters) - Under Armour Inc reported a 1% rise in quarterly revenue on Tuesday as higher demand for its footwear in international markets offset weak performance in the United States.
column6: The company’s net loss narrowed to $17.3 million, or 4 cents per share, in the second quarter ended June 30 from $95.5 million, or 21 cents per share, a year earlier.
column7: Net revenue rose to $1.19 billion from $1.17 billion, roughly in line with analysts’ expectation. (Reporting by Aishwarya Venugopal in Bengaluru)

column4: Nike, Under Armour, among others, urge Trump to remove footwear from tariff list
column5: May 20 (Reuters) - Leading U.S. footwear companies, including Nike Inc and Under Armour, on Monday urged the U.S. President Donald Trump to immediately remove footwear from the proposed tariffs list on goods imported from China.
column6: "The proposed additional tariff of 25 percent on footwear would be catastrophic for our consumers, our companies, and the American economy as a whole," the companies said in a letter here.
column7: President Trump increased tariffs on $200 billion worth of Chinese imports to 25% from 10% earlier in May, a move widely expected to raise prices of thousands of consumer products including clothing and electronics. (Reporting by Nivedita Balu in Bengaluru; Editing by Shailesh Kuber)

column4: Under Armour beats holiday-quarter profit on fewer discounts
column5: (Reuters) - Under Armour Inc beat analysts’ estimates for quarterly profit on Tuesday, as the sportswear maker kept a tight lid on costs and sold more sneakers at full price during the holiday shopping season.
column6: The company’s Class A common shares rose 3.8 percent to $21.58, as investors shrugged off a disappointing current-quarter revenue forecast for North America, its biggest region.
column7: Under Armour struggled with excess inventories for most of last year and was forced to offload more products to discount chains. This added to costs and dented margins.
column8: To cut expenses, the company has shut underperforming stores, slashed jobs and reduced product sourcing costs.
column9: In the fourth quarter, a 12 percent reduction in inventory levels and rising demand for sportswear, which includes Under Armour’s popular Project Rock, Curry 6 and HOVR sneakers, allowed the company to cut back on discounts and beef up its margins.
column10: The company’s online markdowns during the peak holiday period were about 10 to 20 percent lower, compared with a year earlier, according to brokerage William Blair.
column11: Excluding one-time items, Under Armour earned 9 cents per share in the fourth quarter, beating analysts’ average estimate of 4 cents, according to IBES data from Refinitiv.
column12: Adjusted gross margins rose 160 basis points to 45.1 percent, beating analysts’ expectations of 44.8 percent.
column13: North America sales, however, fell 6 percent, as larger rival Nike Inc continued to dominate with a slew of hot product launches.
column14: Under Armour forecast mid-single-digit percentage fall in first-quarter North America sales.
column15: A lack of any major product launches on the horizon has also left analysts skeptical that the company can see a sales recovery in North America any time soon.
column16: “It would appear that Under Armour has hit a ceiling domestically,” Nomura Instinet analyst Simeon Siegel said.
column17: Total revenue rose 1.5 percent to $1.39 billion, edging past estimates of $1.38 billion.

column4: Under Armour expects current-quarter North America revenue to fall
column5: (Reuters) - Under Armour Inc expects a mid-single digit fall in its first-quarter revenue in North America, the footwear maker said on a post-earnings conference call on Tuesday.
column6: Shares of the company, which were up in premarket trading, reversed course to fall about 3 percent.

column4: Under Armour expects current-quarter N.America revenue to fall
column5: Feb 12 (Reuters) - Under Armour Inc expects a mid-single digit fall in its first-quarter revenue in North America, the footwear maker said on a post-earnings conference call on Tuesday.
column6: Shares of the company, which were up in premarket trading, reversed course to fall about 3 percent. (Reporting by Soundarya J in Bengaluru)

column4: Under Armour beats Wall Street estimates for fourth-quarter revenue
column5: Feb 12 (Reuters) - Under Armour Inc, reported quarterly revenue that edged past Wall Street estimates on Tuesday, as the sportswear maker discounted less and sold more sneakers at full price during the holiday season.
column6: The company reported a net income of $4.2 million, or 1 cent per share, in the fourth quarter ended Dec. 31, compared with a loss of $87.9 million, or 20 cents per share, a year earlier, when it took a one-time charge related to changes in the U.S. tax laws.
column7: Net revenue rose to $1.39 billion from $1.37 billion, beating the average analyst estimate of $1.38 billion, according to IBES data from Refinitiv. (Reporting by Uday Sampath in Bengaluru;Editing by Arun Koyyur)

column4: North America to weigh on Under Armour's 2019 revenue growth, shares slide
column5: (Reuters) - Sportswear maker Under Armour Inc UAA.N on Wednesday forecast 2019 revenue growth and profit below Wall Street estimates on expectations of flat sales in North America, triggering a 11 percent drop in its shares.
column6: The company has been struggling to gain market share in the United States, its biggest revenue source, due to fierce competition from Nike Inc NKE.N and Adidas AG ADSGn.DE.
column7: Under Armour’s earnings forecast of 31 cents to 33 cents per share fell short of analysts’ estimate, reflecting the company’s struggle to turn around its North America business. Analysts are expecting the company to post a profit of 35 cents per share in 2019.
column8: The Baltimore, Maryland-based sportswear maker also said it expects revenue to grow between 3 percent and 4 percent in 2019, while analysts were expecting a 5 percent rise, according to IBES data from Refinitiv.
column9: The company’s forecast indicates that a turnaround is still far away, B Riley’s Susan Anderson said.
column10: Addressing investors at its headquarters on Wednesday, the company said it expected 2018 gross margin to be flat, compared with its earlier projection of “flat to down slightly.”
column11: It also forecast compound annual growth rate (CAGR) to be up low single digits in North America between 2020 and 2022, mid-teens in EMEA, low double digits in Latin America and mid-20s in Asia Pacific.
column12: The Hovr smart-shoe maker said it expected to return to a low double-digit revenue growth by 2023.
column13: Canaccord Genuity analyst Camilo Lyon said Under Armour’s 2023 outlook suggested that earnings growth would likely occur toward the second half of the five-year forecast period, calculating a midpoint revenue CAGR of 7.2 percent.
column14: “We would welcome having more confidence in the company’s ability to hit these targets, however, not seeing the company’s innovation or the depth of its pipeline prohibits us from changing a critical pillar of our thesis,” Lyon said, reiterating his “sell” rating on the stock.
column15: Under Armour’s annual sales growth has slowed in the past few years and full-year profit has fallen below estimates in two out of the past five quarters.
column16: Despite Wednesday’s fall, Under Armour’s Class A shares are still up 37.3 percent for the year.
column17: “It is clear (Under Armour) is no longer the growth company it was years ago,” Lyon said.

column4: Under Armour forecasts 2019 revenue growth below estimates
column5: Dec 12 (Reuters) - Under Armour Inc on Wednesday forecast 2019 revenue growth and profit below analysts’ estimates, citing relatively flat results for North America, sending its share down about 11 percent.
column6: The sportswear maker said it expected revenue to grow between 3 percent and 4 percent, while analysts had forecast a rise of 5 percent, according to IBES data from Refinitiv. (Reporting by Nivedita Balu in Bengaluru; Editing by Anil D’Silva)

column4: Kohl's tops same-store sales estimates, raises forecast
column5: Nov 20 (Reuters) - Department store operator Kohl’s Corp reported better-than-expected quarterly same-store sales on Tuesday, benefiting from its revamped stores and merchandise as well as its partnerships with Amazon.com and Under Armour.
column6: Net income rose to $161 million, or 98 cents per share, in the third quarter ended Nov. 3, from $117 million, or 70 cents per share, a year earlier.
column7: Sales at stores open at least 12 months rose 2.5 percent, compared with the 1.74 percent rise expected by analysts, according to IBES data from Refinitiv.
column8: Net sales rose to $4.63 billion from $4.57 billion a year earlier. The company also raised its full-year earnings forecast. (Reporting by Soundarya J in Bengaluru Editing by Saumyadeb Chakrabarty)

column4: Under Armour shares surge as turnaround efforts take hold
column5: (Reuters) - Under Armour Inc's UA.NUAA.N shares surged 25 percent on Tuesday after the sportswear maker's upbeat quarterly earnings and full-year profit forecast underscored the success of its multi-year plan to lower costs and reduce bloated inventory.
column6: The third-largest sportswear maker in the United States has closed stores, cut jobs and rolled back promotions to bolster profit margins as it tries to recover from a bruising fight for market share with bigger rivals Nike Inc NKE.N and Adidas AG ADSGn.DE.
column7: The surge in shares reflect investors’ confidence in the company’s turnaround as well as its expansion in international markets to offset weakness in the United States, where it had fallen behind rivals in the past two years.
column8: The company said on Tuesday it had cut total merchandise by about 1 percent in the quarter, as it deals with excess inventory stemming from 2017 when it expected more demand.
column9: The bloated inventory forced the company to unload products to off-price retailers at lower prices, hitting margins in the past several quarters.
column10: But cost cuts and fewer discounts helped boost margins in the third quarter. Gross margins rose for the first time in several quarters - up 20 basis points to 46.5 percent in quarter, beating the average analyst estimate of 45.8 percent.
column11: Cutting back on stocks of materials such as zippers and buttons by as much as 80 percent and shrinking its vendor base by a quarter also helped.
column12: Under Armour said it was in a better inventory position going into the holiday season, and would sell more of its products through its own channels at full price to help improve margins and the brand’s image.
column13: “Under Armour continues to make progress on its multi-year restructuring, particularly with regards to inventory and cost reduction efforts,” Moody’s Apparel Analyst Mike Zuccaro said.
column14: “While some challenges still remain, the company is stabilizing and is better positioned for improvement in 2019.”
column15: Though North America sales continued to struggle, the company showed strong growth in its international markets of Europe, Middle East and Africa and Latin America. International sales rose 15 percent, while they fell nearly 2 percent in North America.
column16: The maker of Stephen Curry shoes raised its full-year adjusted earnings per share forecast to between 19 cents and 22 cents from a prior guidance of 16 to 19 cents.
column17: Excluding certain items, it earned 25 cents per share, beating analysts’ estimate of 12 cents, according to Refinitiv data.
column18: Under Armour’s shares were up 19.4 percent at $20.07, adding to a 26 percent gain this year.

column4: Under Armour quarterly revenue beats estimates on overseas growth
column5: Oct 30 (Reuters) - Under Armour Inc’s third-quarter revenue topped Wall Street estimates on Tuesday, as its expansion overseas helped offset stagnating sales in the United States.
column6: Net revenue rose 2.4 percent to $1.44 billion, edging past analysts’ average estimate of $1.42 billion, according to Refinitiv data.
column7: Net profit rose to $75.3 million, or 17 cents per share, in the quarter ended Sept. 30, from $54.2 million, or 12 cents per share, a year earlier

column4: Under Armour to cut 400 more jobs in turnaround push, shares rise
column5: (Reuters) - Under Armour Inc UA.NUAA.N announced 400 job cuts on Thursday and raised its forecast for adjusted profit to the high-end of an earlier range, deepening cost-cuts in the face of rising competition from Nike NKE.N and Adidas ADSGn.DE.
column6: The company’s shares rose over 5 percent to $19.74 in early trading, bringing gains for this year to more than 30 percent.
column7: That rise largely reflects a vote of confidence from investors in the company’s shift to focus more on international expansion than a U.S. market where its bigger rivals have muscled it out over the past two years.
column8: Under Armour sales and share value surged in the three years after 2013 on the back of big sponsorship deals with Scottish tennis star Andy Murray and NBA star Steph Curry, grabbing market share from Adidas, Nike and Puma.
column9: Analysts still place it as the world’s third-biggest sportswear maker but rivals have fought back in the years since and shares in the company fell steadily throughout 2016 and 2017.
column10: “Competition still remains an issue,” said Neil Saunders, managing director of GlobalData Retail.
column11: Initial signs from channel checks and online sales are that Nike is also set to get a boost from a controversial ad campaign, launched earlier this month, featuring former NFL player Colin Kaepernick.
column12: Sales in North America have risen only once in Under Armour’s past four quarters, also due to the bankruptcies of sporting goods retailers.
column13: “[Under Armour] has created a lot of confusion with too many ranges and by widening its distribution channels,” Saunders said.
column14: To compensate for patchy sales in North America, Under Armour has ramped up spending on international expansion and improving its online business. International sales have been growing at a double-digit pace over the past few quarters.
column15: The company now expects annual adjusted earnings of 16 to 19 cents per share, compared with a previous estimate of 14 to 19 cents. Analysts on average are expecting 16 cents per share, according to Thomson Reuters I/B/E/S.
column16: This is the second round of job cuts for the Baltimore-based company, which cut 277 jobs last year.
column17: In February, Under Armour said it expects “at least $75 million in savings annually beginning in 2019 and beyond” from restructuring plans in 2017 and 2018.
column18: Under Armour said it expects between $200 million and $220 million in expenses related to the latest rejig, slightly higher than an earlier estimate. The restructuring would reduce 3 percent of its global workforce and would be the final update to its 2018 plan, the company said.
column19: The job cuts are expected to be completed by March 2019.
column20: “Today’s announcement should squash any doubt surrounding the positive trajectory for sustainable operating margin improvement ahead,” Jefferies analyst Randal Konik said.

column4: Under Armour to cut 3 pct of workforce
column5: Sept 20 (Reuters) - Sportswear maker Under Armour Inc said on Thursday it would cut about 3 percent of its global workforce as part of a restructuring plan.
column6: The company said it now expects annual adjusted earnings of 16 to 19 cents per share, compared with its previous forecast of 14 to 19 cents.
column7: The workforce cuts are expected to be completed by March 2019. (Reporting by Aishwarya Venugopal in Bengaluru; Editing by Sai Sachin Ravikumar)

column4: Gun policy, Under Armour weakness hit Dick's Sporting sales
column5: (Reuters) - Dick's Sporting Goods DKS.N reported a bigger-than-expected drop in quarterly same-store sales on Wednesday and forecast further declines this year, hit by tighter gun controls and a drop in Under Armour sales.
column6: Shares in the company fell as much as 10 percent after it posted a 1.9 percent drop in same-store sales, bigger than analysts’ average estimate of a 0.62 percent dip.
column7: Dick’s was one of the first retailers to stop selling assault rifles and high-capacity magazines as well as bar the sale of guns to people under age 21 following a massacre at a Florida high school in February.
column8: The company had predicted that its hunting guns business would be pressurized by the change in policy but said the move should also attract more people to its stores.
column9: Dick’s said on Wednesday it expected annual same-store sales to decline by 3 percent to 4 percent, compared with a 0.3 percent decline in 2017.
column10: Chief Executive Officer Edward Stack said Under Armour sales fell as a result of the sports apparel maker’s decision to expand distribution to a broader range of stores.
column11: Shares in Under Armour Inc UAA.N, for whom Dick's 700 stores have played a major role in efforts to challenge Adidas ADSGn.DE and Nike NKE.N, fell 6 percent to $19.66.
column12: “We had expected comp weakness in hunting and electronics, as well as continued pressure in Under Armour and less benefit from store maturation, but these trends caused more pressure than anticipated,” Telsey analyst Joseph Feldman said.
column13: Still, Dick’s said it expects these headwinds to subside and is confident that its sales trajectory will improve next year. It raised its earnings per share forecast for the year ending February 2019 to between $3.02 and $3.20 versus an earlier forecast of $2.92 to $3.12.
column14: “The improvement in the U.S. athletic market should overcome the weakness in hunting, electronics, and Under Armour as we get into 2019,” Feldman added.
column15: The company’s net income rose 6 percent to $119.40 million, or $1.20 per share. Analysts had estimated $1.06 per share.
column16: Net sales inched up nearly 1 percent to $2.18 billion, below the average Wall Street estimate of $2.24 billion.

column4: Under Armour raises 2018 revenue growth forecast, shares rise
column5: (Reuters) - Sportswear maker Under Armour Inc UA.NUAA.N raised its revenue forecast for the year on the back of higher demand for its athletic wear overseas and a turnaround in its U.S. sales, sending its shares up 8 percent on Thursday.
column6: The company, known for its Stephen Curry 5 basketball shoes, has been spending more to open stores and improve its online offerings in international markets, including China, to grab market share from sneaker giants Nike Inc NKE.N and Adidas AG ADSGn.DE.
column7: That helped fuel a more than 30 percent sales growth in both Europe and Asia in the second quarter ended June 30. North American sales also inched up 1.6 percent, breaking a run of declines dating back to several quarters.
column8: For 2018, the company expects sales growth of 3 percent to 4 percent, up from its previous forecast of low single-digit growth.
column9: However, the company said costs related to reducing its U.S. inventory by selling to off-price stores would weigh on margins for the rest of the year. It now expects 2018 gross margins to be flat to down slightly from a year earlier.
column10: “The question ultimately will be how large can they grow their revenue and at what profitability,” Nomura/Instinet analyst Simeon Siegel said.
column11: The ramp up in spending, however, led the company to report a bigger quarterly loss.
column12: Net loss widened to $95.5 million, or 21 cents per share, as costs rose 10 percent.
column13: Excluding certain items, the Baltimore-based company lost 8 cents per share, in line with analysts’ estimates, according to Thomson Reuters I/B/E/S.
column14: Net revenue rose nearly 8 percent to $1.17 billion, beating analysts’ average estimate of $1.15 billion.

column4: Under Armour reports bigger quarterly loss
column5: July 26 (Reuters) - Sportswear maker Under Armour Inc reported a bigger quarterly loss on Thursday, hit by investments in its direct-to-consumer business and international markets.
column6: The company’s net loss widened to $95.5 million, or 21 cents per share, in the second-quarter ended June 30, from $12.3 million, or 3 cents per share, a year earlier
column7: Net revenue rose nearly 8 percent to $1.17 billion, beating analysts’ average estimate of $1.15 billion, according to Thomson Reuters I/B/E/S. (Reporting by Nivedita Balu in Bengaluru Editing by Saumyadeb Chakrabarty)

column4: Adidas sticks by Kanye West after slavery, Trump remarks
column5: BERLIN (Reuters) - Adidas ADSGn.DE remains committed to the Yeezy brand created by rapper Kanye West despite his comments describing slavery as a choice and praising U.S. President Donald Trump, the sportswear company said on Thursday.
column6: Adidas agreed in 2016 to expand its partnership with West, including opening new stores, after it poached the singer-turned-designer from Nike NKE.N in 2013, helping the German brand recover in the U.S. market in recent years.
column7: However, Adidas faced a call this week from the Care2 petition site to drop the artist after an interview in which he seemed to suggest that 400 years of slavery had been a choice, and also praised Trump for doing the “impossible”.
column8: “It is clear there are some remarks that we don’t support,” Chief Executive Kasper Rorsted told a conference call for journalists, but added: “We are very committed to the Yeezy brand moving forward.”
column9: Rorsted said the partnership was very important for the brand, although it had minimal impact on sales as most Yeezy products are released in limited quantities to generate hype.
column10: Rorsted made the comments after Adidas reported better-than-expected first-quarter net profit, as it outperformed rivals Nike and Under Armour UAA.N in North America.
column11: Adidas shares, up 13 percent in the last three months after it announced a big share buyback in March, were down 1 percent at 0857 GMT, with traders expressing concern about the West partnership and slower growth in Europe.
column12: Sales rose 21 percent in North America, and 26 percent in greater China, but only 5 percent in western Europe and fell 16 percent in Russia, where Rorsted said he saw little prospect for a recovery while sanctions continue.
column13: Nike reported a 6 percent drop in sales in North America in the quarter to Feb. 28, while Under Armour saw flat sales in the region in the first three months of the year.
column14: Adidas said ecommerce sales growth slowed to 27 percent, which Rorsted said was due to fewer product launches in the quarter.
column15: Net profit rose 17 percent to 542 million euros ($650 million), ahead analysts average forecast of 510 million euros as higher prices helped offset currency headwinds and an increase in marketing spending.
column16: Rorsted also highlighted gross margin improvements at struggling fitness brand Reebok, which saw sales return to growth in North America for the first time in years.
column17: Unlike German rival Puma PUMG.DE, Rorsted said he was not too concerned about the prospect of U.S. tariffs on footwear made in China, noting Adidas sources most of its shoes from Vietnam, with Chinese factories mainly producing for the domestic market.

column4: Under Armour forecasts bigger loss as global expansion costs weigh
column5: (Reuters) - Under Armour Inc UAA.NUA.N on Tuesday forecast a bigger-than-expected loss for the second quarter, taking the shine off first-quarter sales that topped Wall Street estimates, as the sportswear maker spends heavily on an overseas expansion.
column6: As growth at Under Armour’s North America business cools after years of double-digit increases in sales, the maker of Curry 5 basketball shoes has turned to markets such as China.
column7: In the United States, the Baltimore-based company faces vicious competition from Nike NKE.N and Germany's Adidas ADSGn.DE. The bankruptcies of a handful of sporting goods stores have also hit sales.
column8: To win more customers, the company has aggressively marketed its Bluetooth-enabled HOVR running shoes and sealed high-profile endorsement deals with celebrities such as Dwayne “The Rock” Johnson — moves that reflect CEO Kevin Plank’s efforts to make Under Armour “a quiet company and a loud brand.”
column9: “Under Armour is buying growth through expansion. There is nothing wrong with this strategy, but it comes with costs attached - which means the contribution to the bottom-line is less than impressive,” Neil Saunders, managing director of GlobalData Retail, said.
column10: Under Armour on Tuesday signaled that spending would continue to rise, forecasting selling, general and administrative (SG&A) expenses to rise at a low double-digit percentage rate in the second quarter. Its SG&A costs rose 3 percent in the first quarter.
column11: Under Armour’s international sales rose 27 percent in the three months ended March 31, making up for flat sales at the North America division that is responsible for 73 percent of overall revenue.
column12: Overall net revenue rose 5.9 percent to $1.19 billion, topping expectations of $1.12 billion, according to Thomson Reuters I/B/E/S.
column13: The company’s Class C shares dipped as much as 6 percent on Tuesday after Under Armour forecast a loss of between 9 and 10 cents per share for the quarter ending June, bigger than the 6-cent loss expected by analysts.
column14: On a conference call with analysts, Chief Financial Officer David Bergman addressed concerns about Under Armour’s expansion leading to higher inventory levels, which one analyst in a report called “out of control.”
column15: Bergman said inventories would rise less than 20 percent by the end of the first half of 2018, down from a prior expectation of 26 percent.
column16: Under Armour’s loss widened to $30.2 million in the first quarter, hurt largely by restructuring costs.
column17: Excluding one-time items, the company broke even on a per-share basis, while analysts had expected a loss of 5 cents per share.

column4: Under Armour's first-quarter sales top estimates
column5: May 1 (Reuters) - Under Armour Inc’s first-quarter sales topped analysts’ forecasts, as the sportswear maker benefited from stronger demand from outside the United States.
column6: The company’s loss widened to $30.2 million or 7 cents per share in the three months ended March 31, from $2.3 million or 1 cent per share a year earlier, hit by restructuring costs of $37.5 million.
column7: Net revenue rose to $1.19 billion from $1.12 billion a year earlier. Analysts on average had estimated revenue of $1.12 billion, according to Thomson Reuters I/B/E/S. (Reporting by Uday Sampath in Bengaluru; Editing by Sai Sachin Ravikumar)
